metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Matplotlib Bars
Creating Bars
With Pyplot, you can use the bar() function to draw bar graphs:
content.html: With Pyplot, you can use the bar() function to draw bar graphs:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x,y)plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A",
"B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x,y)plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
 "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x,y)plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

x = np.array(["A", "B", "C", "D"])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.bar(x,y)
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x,y)plt.show()

content.text: The bar() function takes arguments that describes the layout of the bars.
content.html: The bar() function takes arguments that describes the layout of the bars.

content.text: The categories and their values represented by the first and second argument as arrays.
content.html: The categories and their values represented by the first and second argument as arrays.

content.code_html:
x = ["APPLES", "BANANAS"]
y = [400, 350]
plt.bar(x, y)

content.text: Horizontal Bars
If you want the bars to be displayed horizontally instead of vertically, use the barh() function:
content.html: If you want the bars to be displayed horizontally instead of vertically, use the barh() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.barh(x, y)plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A",
"B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.barh(x, y)plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
 "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.barh(x, y)plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

x = np.array(["A", "B", "C", "D"])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.barh(x, y)
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.barh(x, y)plt.show()

content.text: Bar Color
The bar() and barh() take the keyword argument color to set the color of the bars:
content.html: The bar() and barh() take the keyword argument color to set the color of the bars:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, color = "red")plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A",
"B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, color = "red")plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
 "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, color = "red")plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

x = np.array(["A", "B", "C", "D"])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.bar(x, y, color = "red")
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, color = "red")plt.show()

content.text: Color Names
You can use any of the 140 supported color names .
content.html: You can use any of the 140 supported color names.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, color = "hotpink")plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A",
"B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, color = "hotpink")plt.show()

 "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, color = "hotpink")plt.show()

content.code_html:

import numpy as np

x = np.array(["A", "B", "C", "D"])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.bar(x, y, color = "hotpink")
plt.show()

content.text: Color Hex
Or you can use Hexadecimal color values :

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, color = "#4CAF50")plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A",
"B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, color = "#4CAF50")plt.show()

 "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, color = "#4CAF50")plt.show()

import numpy as np

x = np.array(["A", "B", "C", "D"])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.bar(x, y, color = "#4CAF50")
plt.show()

content.text: Bar Width
The bar() takes the keyword argument width to set the width of the bars:
content.html: The bar() takes the keyword argument width to set the width of the bars:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, width = 0.1)plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A",
"B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, width = 0.1)plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
 "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, width = 0.1)plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

x = np.array(["A", "B", "C", "D"])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.bar(x, y, width = 0.1)
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.bar(x, y, width = 0.1)plt.show()

content.text: The default width value is 0.8
Note: For horizontal bars, use height instead of width .
content.html: Note: For horizontal bars, use height instead of width.

content.text: Bar Height
The barh() takes the keyword argument height to set the height of the bars:
content.html: The barh() takes the keyword argument height to set the height of the bars:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.barh(x, y, height = 0.1)plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A",
"B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.barh(x, y, height = 0.1)plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array(["A", 
 "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.barh(x, y, height = 0.1)plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

x = np.array(["A", "B", "C", "D"])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.barh(x, y, height = 0.1)
plt.show()

  "B", "C", "D"])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.barh(x, y, height = 0.1)plt.show()

content.text: The default height value is 0.8
